opportunities.suggestedAction: Reintroduce a paired-consultant model for this account’s priority roles (or key milestones) and explicitly position it as a value differentiator.

opportunities.title: Proactively address capacity-driven service change
opportunities.description: Korn Ferry communicated that limited capacity ended the dual-consultant approach, which weakened the experience. This is a signal to re-engage, explain the service model, and agree on coverage expectations to protect the relationship.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “We got the message... we have limited capacity, so now we are splitting up and working individually.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Schedule an executive check-in to acknowledge the change, align on the preferred engagement model, and commit to a coverage plan for upcoming searches.

opportunities.title: Make assessments optional and clearly value-based
opportunities.description: Assessment tools were provided but not used because they did not help decision-making for these hires. Better framing and fit-to-purpose guidance would prevent wasted effort and improve perceived relevance.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “We got that for free in some instances, but honestly, I didn't use it... It didn't need that tool, and didn't really help me in my decision making.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Introduce a brief decision guide at kickoff explaining when assessments add value for the role and only include them when the client agrees on the use case.

opportunities.title: Position broader consulting with dedicated experts
opportunities.description: The client does not assume search capability translates to transformation or development work and would re-evaluate providers for those needs. This is an opportunity to expand by introducing the right Korn Ferry experts and demonstrating distinct capability.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “No, because that's a different skill set... I would again pitch and see who's best.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Arrange a targeted introduction to Korn Ferry transformation/development specialists with relevant pharma Japan case examples, positioned separately from search.

opportunities.title: Future executive search support in Japan
opportunities.description: The client has repeatedly used Korn Ferry for multiple search projects over two years and indicates willingness to continue. This suggests ongoing future hiring/search needs where Korn Ferry can secure preferred-partner status.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “That's why we've been keeping working with them over the past two years.” / “Would you use them again? - Yes.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Propose an annual hiring/search roadmap and preferred-terms framework to lock in continuity, speed, and consistent consultant coverage.

opportunities.title: Broaden and deepen candidate sourcing strategy
opportunities.description: The client expected Korn Ferry to surface a wider, higher-caliber slate—especially candidates not already in the committee’s network. Expanding beyond familiar pools and delivering more “surprise” A-plus candidates would increase perceived value-add.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “They didn't really generate the level of the candidates that we thought they should have… Two of the three finalists were my contacts… This is a big enough job that we really should have had A-plus candidates.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Present a revised sourcing plan for future searches that explicitly targets adjacent sectors (e.g., higher ed presidents), includes named target lists, and sets measurable pipeline expectations early.

opportunities.title: Proactively explore adjacent-sector leadership profiles
opportunities.description: Gary explicitly urged the team to look outside traditional sector boundaries (e.g., college presidents) but felt this did not happen. A more imaginative cross-sector mapping approach would better match expectations for a marquee CEO role.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “I had urged them to look broad... like college presidents... and they didn't really do that.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Build an adjacent-sector market map at kickoff and review it with the committee within the first 2–3 weeks to confirm breadth and priority targets.

opportunities.title: Validate relocation and commitment earlier
opportunities.description: Two external finalists withdrew late due to relocation concerns, which the client viewed as preventable with earlier vetting. Earlier confirmation of practical constraints would reduce late-stage disruption and board frustration.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “That should have been fleshed out beforehand… Korn Ferry should have vetted this ahead of time… They should have known those candidates were not going to move.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Implement a mandatory early-stage commitment checkpoint (relocation, compensation, timing, family constraints) before candidates advance to final assessment/testing.

opportunities.title: Maintain consistent senior ownership through close
opportunities.description: The client perceived reduced prioritization and ownership after the lead partner’s temporary absence. Stronger continuity planning and visible leadership coverage would preserve confidence through the final stages.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “Once she was gone, it felt less prioritised… It just felt a little bit… an ownership thing.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Define a named deputy lead and continuity plan at kickoff, with scheduled senior check-ins that continue uninterrupted through finalist selection and closing.

opportunities.title: Recalibrate search earlier when pipeline narrows
opportunities.description: Late-stage suggestions to reopen the search and shift profiles felt reactive and undermined confidence. Earlier data-driven recalibration would help maintain momentum and avoid end-stage surprises.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “It got off to such a good start... and then it sort of skidded off the runway… [reopening the search] was experienced as reactive rather than proactive.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Set predefined pipeline health triggers (e.g., number of qualified/committed candidates by week X) that automatically prompt an early strategy reset with the committee.

opportunities.title: Executive sponsor follow-up to rebuild confidence
opportunities.description: As an NPS 7 passive with clear late-stage dissatisfaction, the relationship would benefit from a senior-level debrief and service recovery. This can convert constructive feedback into renewed trust for future work.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “It was just disappointing… It felt less prioritised at the firm.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Have a senior Korn Ferry leader conduct a structured post-search debrief, acknowledge gaps, share process changes (sourcing breadth, commitment vetting, continuity), and agree on success metrics for any future engagement.

opportunities.title: Future board and C-suite leadership searches
opportunities.description: Gary leads nomination and governance and chaired the CEO search committee, indicating likely ongoing needs for senior leadership and governance-related searches. A proactive plan for upcoming leadership needs could position Korn Ferry for repeat work.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “Chair of the Board Search Committee… responsibility for leading the nomination and governance committee… search for a new Chief Executive Officer.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Offer a forward-looking leadership and succession roadmap discussion (CEO direct reports, key executives, and board refresh cycles) to identify upcoming search needs.

opportunities.title: Expand into assessment and onboarding support
opportunities.description: The client valued Korn Ferry’s assessment infrastructure (including psychologist involvement) and the CEO outcome is positive, creating an opening to extend into structured onboarding and leadership assessment for the broader team.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “They even brought in… a psychologist on their staff, and that was a useful session… The guy's doing a great job.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Propose an onboarding and first-180-days effectiveness package for the new CEO and optional assessment/coaching for the executive team to sustain the successful placement.

opportunities.title: Repair relationship with primary client contact
opportunities.description: Julie feels sidelined when Korn Ferry engages senior stakeholders in ways that diminish her role. This creates a real risk of losing future work despite strong technical delivery.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “They're managing up... in a way that felt somewhat disrespectful to me and my role.” / “It definitely feels like a diminishment of my role.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Schedule an executive-level reset with Julie to acknowledge the impact, agree engagement norms, and confirm she is the primary decision partner for day-to-day governance.

opportunities.title: Address fee dispute and rebuild trust
opportunities.description: The additional fee tied to a CEO-sourced candidate was experienced as transactional and threatens repeat business. The dismissive response when concerns were raised amplified the damage.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “It just seemed... penny smart, pound foolish... That behavior would make me not want to work with them again.” / “They shut her down immediately.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Proactively revisit the specific fee incident, offer a goodwill adjustment or clarified credit policy, and align on a partnership-based commercial approach for future searches.

opportunities.title: Clarify hybrid sourcing and fee rules upfront
opportunities.description: Unclear expectations on how internally sourced candidates are handled creates friction late in the process. A clear, pre-agreed policy would prevent future disputes and protect the relationship.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “Clarify shared ownership during hybrid candidate sourcing... align on how internally sourced candidates are handled.” (summary) / “additional fee charged following a CEO-sourced candidate” (issue described)
opportunities.suggestedAction: Add a standard kickoff module that documents hybrid sourcing scenarios, ownership, and fee treatment with written sign-off before candidate outreach begins.

opportunities.title: Reduce client burden for logistics and coordination
opportunities.description: Julie believes Korn Ferry is relying too heavily on Zayo for scheduling and operational logistics, which undermines perceived value. Rebalancing responsibilities would improve the experience and efficiency.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “They rely on us very heavily for everything logistical... It feels like they kind of expect us to do their logistics.” / “We are paying... for them to do it.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Assign dedicated search operations support (or clearly defined coordinator ownership) and provide a logistics plan/RACI so Korn Ferry owns scheduling, comms, and tracking.

opportunities.title: Fix template reuse and process continuity
opportunities.description: Repeated requests for previously shared templates and materials create avoidable friction and signal poor internal continuity. A consistent process repository would reduce duplication and speed delivery.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “They were like, 'Oh, we don't have that template. Can you send it again?'”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Implement a client-specific engagement folder and standardized artifacts checklist so all team members can access agreed templates and prior materials.

opportunities.title: Adopt more collaborative issue-handling behaviors
opportunities.description: When concerns were raised, the response was perceived as closed rather than collaborative, increasing the likelihood of switching firms. Improving how objections are handled would strengthen partnership perception.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “They shut her down immediately.” / “Behaviour outweighs technical competence... ‘This behavior would make me choose someone else.’”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Coach search leaders on a consistent escalation and resolution approach (listen, validate, options, agree next steps) and ensure Julie receives timely follow-up after any concern.

opportunities.title: Support fast-paced PE operating cadence
opportunities.description: Zayo’s private equity environment drives expectations for speed, responsiveness, and low-friction execution. Korn Ferry can better tailor delivery to match this cadence and reduce operational drag.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “We’re a PE… we move fast.” / “They have been unbelievably responsive... they moved very quickly.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Offer a PE-optimized search operating model (rapid kickoff, weekly decision checkpoints, tight SLAs, and streamlined logistics) aligned to Zayo’s pace.

opportunities.title: Expand assessments and leadership competency work
opportunities.description: Julie values Korn Ferry’s psychometric tools and leadership competency models, indicating an opportunity to broaden these offerings beyond current use. This could deepen the relationship outside of executive search.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “We use their psychometric tools for assessment, and they were very, very good.” / “The quality of the work... on the consultancy side... is high.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Propose a roadmap to extend assessments/competency work into broader leadership development, succession planning, or selection processes tied to upcoming roles.

opportunities.title: Post-hire leadership development planning support
opportunities.description: Tim intends to use Korn Ferry’s psychometric assessment outputs to build a development plan, indicating a need for structured post-hire coaching/development support.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “We use their psychometric tools for assessment... It will be used for a development plan, yeah, absolutely.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Offer a packaged post-placement development plan service (e.g., debrief + coaching + 90/180-day plan) tied to the assessment results.

opportunities.title: Broaden psychometric assessments beyond hiring
opportunities.description: The client values Korn Ferry’s psychometrics and has positive experiences with interpretation, creating an opening to extend assessments to wider leadership/team development use cases.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “We use their psychometric tools for assessment, and they were very, very good.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Propose an assessment-led leadership capability program for the senior team (e.g., leadership profiles, team effectiveness, succession insights).

opportunities.title: Support outward-facing leadership capability build
opportunities.description: Tim flagged outward-facing credibility as a growing organisational priority, suggesting opportunities for targeted executive search, assessment, and development focused on external influence roles.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “The most important thing for us is that our outward facing activities are done by really high-quality people.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Initiate a conversation about upcoming roles and capability gaps in external affairs/advocacy leadership and offer a combined search + assessment + onboarding plan.

opportunities.title: Introduce remuneration benchmarking and advisory
opportunities.description: Tim has previously used and valued Korn Ferry remuneration consulting, indicating potential to reintroduce this service for pay benchmarking or reward strategy as needs arise.
opportunities.supportingQuote: Past experiences with “remuneration consulting were described positively.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Share a light-touch reward/benchmarking offer and ask about any upcoming pay reviews, role leveling, or market competitiveness concerns.

opportunities.title: Stay close until organisation reaches scale
opportunities.description: Tim suggested broader consulting may not fit until the organisation has more scale; this is a signal to maintain proactive contact and offer right-sized options rather than waiting for inbound demand.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “I think we'd need a bit more scale before we went to somebody of Korn Ferry size to do other work like that.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Set a quarterly check-in and present modular, scalable offerings (pilot engagements) that feel proportionate to Logistics UK’s size.

opportunities.title: Maintain structured weekly updates and accessibility
opportunities.description: The weekly cadence and ad hoc availability were explicitly valued; preserving this approach is a concrete action to sustain the experience quality in future searches.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “We had one scheduled weekly call throughout the process... and they were always available for other queries.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Standardise the weekly governance rhythm and response-time expectations as part of the engagement kickoff for future assignments.

opportunities.title: Continue first-class interview logistics and admin
opportunities.description: Administrative and logistical coordination was a standout strength; ensuring this remains consistent will protect a key differentiator in the client experience.
opportunities.supportingQuote: “Their admin support was excellent... all the logistical arrangements... it was just first class, all the way through.”
opportunities.suggestedAction: Document and replicate the logistics playbook used on this search and confirm responsibilities/timelines at the start of each assignment.

opportunities.title: Follow up on passive NPS score
opportunities.description: The client is a passive (NPS 7), which signals moderate satisfaction but risk of churn if value is not reinforced. A structured follow-up can uncover what would move them to a 9–10 and strengthen the partnership.
opportunities.supportingQuote: NPS: 7 (passive)
opportunities.suggestedAction: Schedule a 30-minute debrief with Luke to understand the drivers of the 7 score and agree 2–3 concrete improvements and next steps.
